title: State of emergency declared as California wildfires ravage homes
text:
High winds are stoking the flames which are devastating much of California (Picture: Getty Images)

With nearly 200,000 people ordered to leave their homes as wildfires as ferocious winds spread wildfires though bone-dry vegetation, California’s governor declared a statewide emergency yesterday.

Millions of residents remain without power after the state’s largest utility company cut electricity as a precaution to prevent more areas from igniting.

More evacuations are expected over the next few days, with more strong gusts expected to whip up the inferno known as the Kincade Fire.

In a statement, state governor Gavin Newsom said officials were deploying ‘every resource available’ to respond to the wildfires.

A large blaze in Northern California’s wine country was powered by winds exceeding 102mph and had grown to over 85 square miles.

Firefighters battle the Kincade Fire along in Healdsburg, California (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Fire and embers blow around a burnt utility truck in Healdsburg (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

The fire has burnt over 30,000 acres and has led to nearly 200,000 evacuations (Picture: Getty Images)

Officials said containment had dropped to five per cent and that at least 94 structures had been destroyed.

Meanwhile in the San Francisco Bay Area, two grass fires briefly halted traffic on an Interstate bridge and came dangerously close to homes in Vallejo.

Another blaze closed a stretch of motorway cutting through the state capital as smoke obstructed drivers.

In the south, 18 structures were destroyed by a wildfire in the Santa Clarita area near Los Angeles, which was contained by 70 per cent as of last night.

The biggest evacuation was in Northern California’s Sonoma County where 180,000 people were told to pack up and leave, many in the middle of the night.

To prevent its power lines from sparking in the high winds and setting off more blazes, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) said yesterday that preventative shut-offs impacted 965,000 customers.

Power supplies have been cut off to prevent more flames being sparked (Picture: Reuters)

The skies are illuminated with an orange glow as the wildfires rage on (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Firefighters discuss how to approach the scene as a home burns near grape vines in Healdsburg (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Another 100,000 lost electricity because of strong gusts, bringing the number of residents impacted by blackouts to nearly 2.7 million people.

PG&E officials say they are expecting strong winds to pick up again tomorrow and have notified 500,000 households – more than 1 million people – they are likely to have their power turned off for the third time in a week.

Some of those customers might not have their power restored from the current outage before the next major shutdown, which would leave them without electricity for five days or longer, said the company’s emergency preparedness and response director Mark Quinlan.

California’s state governor Gavin Newsom said officials were deploying ‘every resource available’ (Picture: Getty Images)

More than a million people are likely to have their power turned off for a third time in a week (Picture: Getty Images)

Heavy winds are helping to spread flames rapidly across the state (Picture: Getty Images)

The fear that the winds could blow embers and spread fire across a major highway prompted authorities to expand evacuation orders covering parts of Santa Rosa, a city of 175,000 that was devastated by a wildfire two years ago.

More than 300 people slept inside an auditorium filled with cots and wheeled beds in the city’s main fairground last night while scores more stayed in a separate building with their pets.

Yesterday Sonoma County Sheriff’s Office tweeted: ‘This is the largest evacuation that any of us … can remember. Take care of each other.’

It is not yet known what caused the fires, but (PG&E) said on Thursday that a ‘broken jumper’ wire in one of its transmission towers was found near to where the inferno started.

description: Wildfires across California have forced 200,000 people from their homes as Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) shut off power as a precaution.
